awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: RUI: New Directions in Kolmogorov Complexity and Network Information Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
Data communication in systems with multiple senders and receivers raises difficult problems caused by the possibility of complex data correlation patterns, network topologies, and interaction scenarios. Traditionally, these problems have been tackled using tools from Information Theory (IT), which assumes that the data has been produced according to a certain generative model.  In practice, most of the time the generative model is not known. Even if it is known, it is often more complicated than the models typically used in theoretical studies. This project will use tools from Algorithmic Information Theory (AIT, also known as Kolmogorov complexity), which equates the information in a piece of data with its minimal description length.  The advantage is that the new approach does not rely on any model, and consequently the results obtained this way are valid in more general circumstances. The problems that will be studied are of interest to computer scientists, electrical engineers, and mathematicians. The project will promote a deep and dynamic exchange of ideas between these communities. This project will produce new insights in Kolmogorov complexity and communication complexity. These areas have applications in computational complexity, machine learning, constructive combinatorics, and other fields. The results will likely have an impact in many of these areas. The project will allow undergraduate and graduate students to participate in research activities that have a strong theoretical flavor and the promise of real-world applications.

The project is timely and realistic because it has recently become apparent that some interesting questions (for instance, source coding of non-ergodic sources), which cannot be approached with tools based on Shannon entropy, can be solved in the AIT framework. In the other direction, there has been recent progress in some classical problems in Kolmogorov complexity inspired from results and techniques from IT. The project will: (1) isolate, understand, and develop certain aspects of Kolmogorov complexity that are particularly relevant for data communication; (2) use the newly-developed tools to make progress in outstanding problems in network communication such as channel coding, network coding, interactive protocols, and others; and (3) use the insights from the communication setting to advance the theory of Kolmogorov complexity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: This project has studied the relation between communication and computation. The traditional  setting is given by Information Theory, which assumes that data is generated by a probabilistic process, whose structural properties (e.g., independence, ergodicity, various statistics, etc.) are at least partially used in constructions and analysis. In contrast, much of  this project has been done in the setting of Algorithmic Information Theory, which defines in a natural manner the amount of information in each individual object (this is its Kolmogorov complexity) and does not assume any generative model for the provenance of data.  This approach has lead to  very general results that are valid with few assumptions.

The undertaken research has considered communication via both noiseless channels (this is called source coding or data compression) and noisy channels (channel coding or error correcting codes).  The following is an informal presentation  of some outcomes of the project.

- We have shown that there exists an optimal universal compressor that is efficient.   For any given pair (Compressor, Decompressor), no matter how slow Compressor is, or even if Compressor is non-computable, the optimal compressor is a fixed algorithm that produces in polynomial time a codeword that is almost as short as the one produced by Compressor. The cost is that the corresponding decompressor may be inefficient. A similar result holds for distributed compression.

- Channel coding is the task of making communication resilient to noise. Is this possible if there is no apriori information about the distortion made by the channel?  An encoder that would do this task is called an universal code. The project has shown that universal codes exist provided the encoding and the decoding functions share randomness, which is unavailable to the channel.   There are two parameters of interest: the rate, which is the ratio between the message length  and the codeword length n, and the number of shared random bits.  Tight lower and upper bounds for these parameters have been derived. The universal encoding has polynomial runtime, but the distortion-dependent decoding procedures are  in general not efficient.   For some weaker classes of channels, we have constructed universal codes with polynomial-time encoding and decoding.

- In many natural circumstances, coding is essentially an online matching process. Indeed as strings are generated by some source, coding amounts to assigning them codewords on-the-fly.  A more general problem is dynamic matching, which is defined as follows. In a bipartite graph G, left nodes represent clients and right nodes represent servers. Clients can be active or idle and they can switch between the two states. When a client becomes active a neighbor server must be assigned to it in an online manner, and when a client becomes idle the assigned neighbor is released.  We have shown that bipartite graphs with large expansion, after a minor modification, admit fast dynamic matching, where ``fast''   means that each match is done in time polynomial in the logarithm of the number of left nodes,  and the left degree. The results  have been used  to improve the state-of-the-art constructions of certain communication networks and of the bitvector data structure  for dynamic sets.

Broader Impacts: The grant has revealed fundamental properties of some  basic objects in Information Theory, which have been used in diverse areas such as network communication, network design, combinatorics, machine learning, computational complexity.   Findings from this grant were published in peer-reviewed theoretical computer science journals  and conferences resulting in broad dissemination.
